Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Ion-Beam-assisted Glancing Angle Deposition Tool (iGLAD) for 3D Nanostructure Thin Film Preparation with in-situ Ellipsometry control

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will enable the creation of a new tool - Ion-Beam-assisted Glancing Angle Deposition Tool (iGLAD) - for preparation of highly-defined sculptured columnar thin films (SCTFs), an emerging class of highly-ordered, nano-engineered materials with high surface area. The iGLAD tool will feature ion beam sources in addition to traditional evaporation sources, providing multiple growth modes. The ion sources will allow for substrate cleaning and prepatterning without sample exposure to the ambient environment prior to fabrication, thereby enhancing control of the ordered arrangement of the nanomaterials. The iGLAD tool will feature a novel adaptive optics design for in-situ real-time diagnostics to track substrate movements throughout the fabrication process. This will allow, for the first time, monitoring and control of the nanomaterial formation process by generalized spectroscopic ellipsometry--providing valuable insights into nanomaterial formation mechanisms and strategies for improving their structural, geometrical and material properties.

The iGLAD tool will make a new class of nanomaterials widely available and will enable unique research training and experience for internal and external students and researchers. The instrumentation will substantially advance research in nanomaterials fabrication and control and understanding of structure-property relations and design of novel nano-engineered optical materials. It will enable new biosensors and new chromatography principles, new tissue engineering and gene delivery concepts, new high-speed electronics, energy storage, and environmental sensing research. This research will inspire new applications for highly-ordered 3D nanomaterials with potentially transformative scientific and commercial impacts, which are further enhanced by partnerships with national laboratories and private sector firms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ion-beam-based deposition of thin films is a commonly employed technology to fabricate, among others, materials with high melting points or high formation energies. Thin film deposition under glancing angle of particle incidence is known to result in nanostructured columnar growth.

This project developed a new tool, ion-beam-assisted glancing angle deposition (iGLAD), for preparation of sculptured columnar thin films (SCTFs), an emerging class of highly-ordered, nano-engineered materials with large surface area. The new development combines the advantages of GLAD (glancing angle deposition) with ion-beam-assisted deposition (IBAD). These advantages are well known for homogeneous (solid) thin film growth. IBAD provides separate control over assist ion energy and density to achieve and maintain a balance between particle removal and particle adsorption.  The ion bombardment allows controlled etching (shaping) of STF's, and thereby preparation of highly-defined STF features. The iGLAD tool is equipped with a novel adaptive in-situ optical mirror design, which permits in-situ monitoring of nanostructure growth using spectroscopic ellipsometry. The adaptive mirror design accounts for necessary motion of the substrate surface via two axes of rotation during typical iGLAD procedures.

The tools and methods that were created in this project are innovative in that they offer to growth highly-ordered, nano-engineered thin films from a wide range of materials while the growth of the thin films can be monitored in-situ by spectroscopic ellipsometry. The tool permits creation of heterostructures formed from nanostructured columnar materials. The tool further permits use of ion-beam erosion to create substrate pre-patterning and substrate cleaning prior to nanostructure deposition.

The tool is anticipated to make impact on research that is dedicated towards the design of novel nano-engineered optical materials, new biosensors, and new chromatography principles, new tissue engineering, and gene delivery concepts, new high-speed electronics, energy storage, and environmental sensing research. The iGLAD tool has become part of the facilities in the Center for Nanohybrid Functional Materials (CNFM) at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. CNFM is an interdisciplinary research center, which is comprised of scientists from multiple institutions of higher education in Nebraska working in fields such as physics, chemistry, biology, biological systems engineering, electrical engineering and environmental engineering. The center is focused on research at the cross section of traditional material science and engineering, and life science. Nanostructured surfaces and sculptured thin films fabricated by GLAD are the physical base and changes to functionality, as required by the specific application, are achieved by further hybridizing SCTFs using atomic layer deposition surface coatings, polymer infiltration, aptamer attachment, cell attachment or attachment of environmentally hazardous substances, for example.

This project has also had a direct and broad impact on human resource development through the undergraduate and graduate students who were mentored and conducted research under this project.  The iGLAD tool enabled unique research training and experience for internal and external students and researchers in Electrical Engineering and Materials Science, where participants were trained in design of vacuum equipment, in preparation of nanomaterials and in mathematical modeling of optical systems and ellipsometry data analysis.

Research results generated from the iGLAD system have been disseminated in talks at the UNL Summer Research Fair, the NSF MRSEC PSPIN organized Conference of Undergraduate Women in Physical Science, and the Conference of Magnetics and Magnetic Materials.

Outreach efforts involving high school students and middle school students were held as part of this effort. Students were taught simple principles of nanomaterial preparations and computer-assisted design. Students were involved in presenting at summer research workshops organized by UNL Student affairs. Training and research experiences gained have helped to prepare students in fulfilling national areas of need for future scientists and professionals in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
